text: CLOSE ON: a word carved in stone: 'DREAMS'.
PULL BACK to reveal the full inscription:

head_text.subj: 'FOR IN THAT SLEEP OF DEATH WHAT DREAMS MUST COME.'

text: It's carved on a large obelisk grave marker. Beneath the  inscription is a name: THIBAULT, and dates: 1861-1917.
PULL FURTHER BACK: Perched on the marker is a stone effig the angel of death, wings spread wide, half-smile on her  face.
AND FURTHER BACK: Ropes are wrapped around the marker. Th ropes tighten, and the marker is suddenly PULLED OVER, th CAMERA taking off with it --

The marker is dragged along, through deep grass ... then a bump it's on a dirt road, then over a bridge. It's drag by a team of horses. Rain starts to fall. The marker pull away, continuing on toward --
Burgess Manor, a dark outline against the gray marble sky
The garage was once the carriage house. Several luxury ca circa 1930s, fill the bays. The marker lies in an empty o Two men stand nearby.
One is RODERICK BURGESS. A commanding presence, radiating charisma both disturbing and mesmerizing. He is in his ea twenties, but his soul is much older -- and darker.
The other is SMITH. Middle-aged, face drawn, he peers out the garage furtively. He's worried, preoccupied. A white  clerical collar is almost hidden beneath his coat and sca
(hopefully)
The rain will wash out the tracks ...
Burgess moves slowly to the marker.
I've found it. Crowley couldn't. Mathers  couldn't. Only I could.
I didn't see anybody on the  road ...
Burgess isn't listening to him; he's preoccupied with the marker. He examines it gleefully, reverently.
Thibault had it stolen from the Vatican  Library -- that's common knowledge. But  then it disappeared. He told Yeats he'd  destroyed it. But he didn't. He couldn't.  And now -- I've found it.
I don't think anyone saw me.
Burgess finally looks at the man. Cocks his head, amused.
Don't worry, Vicar. No one saw you. No  one knows what you've done -- except you  and me. And God. (insinuating)
Just like your other little ...  peccadilloes.
The Vicar shuts his eyes in pain.
Please ... (looks at Burgess)
What they say is true. You are the most  wicked man alive.
(chuckles)
I've always liked that title.
He grabs up a sledge hammer, startling the other man -- a intended. He smiles, and SMASHES the hammer down on the  marker. Another blow. Another --
The marker is hollow. Hidden inside is a large oilskin  bundle. Burgess drops the sledge. Lifts out the bundle.
Burgess unwraps it carefully. Inside is a thick book.
The Magdalene Grimoire. Finally.
The book is heavy, leather bound, brittle with age. Burge pages through it greedily. It is filled with tiny, crampe writing, arcane diagrams, drawings.
That's it then? You can do it now? You  can ... capture the angel of death?
Death isn't an angel. She's one of the  Endless ... who existed long before  angels ... and will exist long after the  final cherubim has sung its last hosanna.
Heresy.
For your sake, hope it's not. The  Magdalene Grimoire is all the Order of  Ancient Mysteries needed. With it, we  will summon and imprison Death. (beat)
And I will command who shall live ... and  who shall die.
Then ... you'll keep our bargain? (no answer)
Please -- you'll keep your promise?
Of course, Vicar. You have my word. You  won't die. And you will never have to  stand in the judgment of your God. (clasps him on the shoulder; cheery)
Good night.
He exits the garage, for the main house. Smith looks down the marker, at the shattered effigy of death.
Thank God --
He catches himself, realizing he shouldn't be praying. Hi eyes fill with tears; he slumps.
What have I done?
Candles burn in the darkness. Robed figures inscribe a la circle on the floor -- chalk white against the black ston Runic characters decorate it.
It is midnight, Lord Magus.
It is time. Elspeth, love..?
A beautiful YOUNG WOMAN nods adoringly. She crouches on a fours at Burgess' feet.
Items are placed on her back: a ceremonial bowl, inside w floats a human heart. A long twisted knife. A feather. Co The Magdalene Grimoire. She is a human altar.
Burgess opens the book. He begins to intone, displaying t items as he names them:

I give you coin I made from a stone. I  give you a song I stole from the dirt. I  give you a knife from under the hills.  And a stick I stuck through a dead man's  eye. I give you a claw I ripped from a  rat. I give you a name, and the name is  lost.
He jabs his forearm with the knife. Blood drips onto the  feather.
I give you blood from out of my vein, and  a feather I pulled from an angel's wing.
He throws the feather into the circle.
I summon with poison, and summon with  pain. I open the way and open the gates.  Come.
The acolytes echo the word 'Come.'
I summon you in the names of the old  lords. Namtar. Allatu. Morax. Naberius.  Klesh. Vepar. Maymon. We summon.
The acolytes chant 'Come.'
From the dark they call you ... into the  dark they call you. Coin and song, knife  and stick ...
In the center of the circle, the air SHIMMERS --
Claw and name, blood and feather ... Here  in the darkness ...
The air SOLIDIFIES, taking shape --  The acolytes echo 'Here in the darkness.'
Here in the darkness, we summon you  together. COME!
There is FLASH  --
-- and a black-cloaked FIGURE materializes in mid-air.
His head and face are covered by a HELM that looks like t skull of some dead ancient god (which it is).
A large, vibrant heart-shaped RUBY adorns his neck.
A small leather POUCH hangs from one hand.
-- and then the figure collapses. He lies splayed on the  floor, in the center of the circle.
The acolytes are hushed, amazed.
We did it. I don't believe it. We did it --
No. We failed. This isn't Death. Damn it  to hell.
Silence from the others as Burgess considers the figure.
Even so ... strip him.
The Acolyte nods, reaches across the circle --
-- and SCREAMS as his arm TWISTS violently, torqued by so unseen force. Burgess shoves him away from the circle.
Fool! If you'd broken the circle, he  could have escaped!
He grabs Elspeth by the hair, slashes with the knife --
Elspeth's head lolls to one side. Burgess catches her bef she collapses.
My god --
Burgess lets Elspeth fall to the ground. He holds his han up like a surgeon. They are stained with Elspeth's blood.
Careful not to break the circle, Burgess steps close to t captured FIGURE. With bloody hands he strips off the cloa
He takes the ruby.
He takes the pouch.
And then he removes the helm --

The face revealed is bone white, framed by jet black hair aquiline nose and high cheekbones, a face carved from fin marble -- save the eyes. These are obsidian, deep as the  universe -- and staring directly at Burgess.
He is the personification of dream.
He is SANDMAN.
Burgess draws back, unsettled.
(shaken)
... I think, at day's end, this will have  been a very profitable evening's work.
With a gesture, he orders the acolytes out. Burgess conti to stare at Sandman as he backs out of the room.
The door to the room pivots on an axis; the other side is brick. It is clearly a secret room. The door swings shut.
Sandman lies on the floor, unmoving. And then --
-- a single, small tear slips down his cheek --
From somewhere in the empty room comes the SOUND of water DRIPPING, slowly. In the corner, a drop of water slips fr pipe, courses down the wall to the floor.

A scratchy recording of 'Dream a Little Dream of Me' fade and out. We see images, drifting, dreamlike, drawn from n reels, photographs, drawings: A bread line. Gandhi. Astai and Rogers, dancing. Flagpole sitting and dance marathons Hitler at a rally ...
CLOSE ON: Sandman's eyes. He's sitting up now, hugging hi knees to his chest. But still unmoving.
Burgess, nearly twenty years older, sits in a chair oppos him, studying him.
I know you can grant me boons. Power.  Immortality. A promise you won't seek  revenge. (beat)
Well? I know you can understand me. Say  something!
Sandman does not respond. Does not move. Just stares.
Damn you.
The door pivots, and ALEX BURGESS pushes in. He's seven, he wants nothing more than to please his father. He carri large folio, dusty and falling apart.
Sir! I found it!
Yes, Alex?
See? Here. In the Paginarum Fulvarum.
He leafs through the folio. It is filled with old drawing and paintings. We catch quick glimpses of figures titled  Destiny, Death, Desire, figures we will learn more of lat
You said he had to be one of the Endless.  But it wasn't Death. And it's not Desire,  or Despair -- or Destiny. That'd been  brilliant if you'd caught him -- um ...
Burgess has fixed him with a stern look, humbling him.
Uh, anyway ... Here.
He finds the drawing he's looking for, displays it:
A Heirmonyous Bosch-like portrait of Sandman in his helm cloak. Terrifying. The drawing is inscribed 'Here is said thee Kinge of Dremes.'
See? He's Dream. (reading)
Morpheus, Lord Shaper. the Prince of  Stories ... the Sandman.
Burgess takes the folio, examines it, nodding.
Yes. I was hoping you'd work it out on  your own one day. And you have. Well  done, Alex.
Thank you, father --
Father?
(chastised)
Thank you, Lord Magus. (gathers his courage)
Sir ... Since you know his true name,  can't you make him do what you want?
Cretin. That kind of magick is too  trifling for him and his ilk. The Endless  are not mortal
But if they're gods --
They are not gods. Gods come and go. Gods  fade away.
But ... are we safe? What if his brothers  and sisters come after us?
Burgess broods on this ... glances at a shelf. On it lie  Sandman's helm, pouch and ruby. He fingers the helm.
Protection can be had. Deals can be  struck ...  (to Alex)
You've never seen a summoning, have you,  son? Tonight, you will. We'll conjure a  demon of hell. And trade this -- (lifts the helm)
-- for our safety. (more)
(turns to leave)
Inform the acolytes.
Yes, Lord Magus. But what about ... what  about him?
He will not get out unless the circle is  broken. And the circle will not be broken  unless I order it.
He leaves, Alex trailing. Sandman watches them go..
In the corner, a DROP of water slips from a pipe, courses down the wall to the floor. Twenty years has worn a chann in the stone; the drop flows along it. And then another .

More time goes by, more images, dreamlike: McCarthy in th Senate. Lenin reviewing a May Day parade. Walt Disney ope Disneyland. Hula hoops, 3-D movies, Elvis. The KKK marchi on Washington. All accompanied by the Everly Brothers'  version of 'All I Ever Do is Dream.'
The door pushes open. Burgess enters, slightly drunk. At  sixty, he's still handsome and vital. With him is --
RACHEL. Beautiful in the extreme, radiating sexual heat.  Dressed in the counterculture style of the day. She is  giggling -- then draws up short at the sight of Sandman.
My God ... it's true.
She circles Sandman slowly.
Alex, now in his twenties, has followed them into the roo he watches Rachel's every step.
He's magnificent. And you caught him,  Lord Magus?
Burgess smiles -- but it fades when Alex speaks.
Actually, it was a mistake. He was trying  to --
Shut up, Alex.
Is he a demon?
(shakes his head)
He's more dangerous than any demon I've  known.
He scoops up the pouch from the shelf.
Here. This is what I told you about. (opens the pouch)
The stuff that dreams are made of ...
(to himself)
'Made on.' Quote it right, you old idiot  ...
He goes unheard as Burgess sprinkles some of the sand int his own hand. It sparkles. He holds it out to Rachel.
No matter how much you take out, there's  always some left ... Try it.
How do I ..? Sniff it?
Sniff it, swallow it, rub it on your skin  ... pour it in your eyes ... it doesn't  matter.
Rachel considers. Puts one finger in her mouth, moistenin it, rolls it in the sand. With a wicked grin, eyes never  leaving Burgess', she trails her hand down toward her jea
Burgess stares, panting slightly --
Her fingers slips beneath the waistband. Between her legs
Oh, Rachel ... You are a wild one ...
She smiles, shows her teeth -- her eyes go wide. She is  seeing something beautiful, rapturous. She is seeing life a dream.
Oh ... oh, my ...
Roderick sets the pouch down, moves to Rachel. Begins to  nuzzle her neck, undress her. She responds to him --
-- but her eyes never leave the pouch.
Alex's gaze lingers on Rachel as he backs away. Then he s discreetly out of the room.
And Sandman continues to watch ... and wait ...
The door opens. Alex slips in, followed by Rachel.
Is he really what old Roddy says he is?
I don't know ... Stupid old Roddy  should've died by now and left me in  charge ... he really can work some sort  of magic ...
That sand ... that was magic ...
Alex grabs the pouch. Considers, then takes the ruby as w He heads for the door. Rachel catches him.
Please ... just a little.
Alex considers. Opens the pouch. Rachel pinches out some  sand, sniffs it. It takes effect immediately, transportin her. Alex grabs her hand.
Come on ...
She pulls against him, grabs for the pouch. He lets her t it. She clutches it. One last look at Sandman; then she  allows herself to be led from the room.
Sandman gazes after them.
In the corner, a DROP of water slips from the pipe, cours down the wall to the floor. Flows along the channel, whic now leads to a small pool.
More time goes by. Nixon, victorious over McGovern. An ES meeting, slam dancing punks, a 'Star Wars' line. The  Ayatollah exhorting a mob. The song is 'Dreamweaver.' It  skips.
A man -- call him DAVID -- sleeps fitfully in the one-roo efficiency apartment. He wears the pants and shirt of a  postal uniform; the rest is scattered on the floor.
The TV is on, volume low, showing Bicentennial celebratio news footage. Traffic NOISE comes from outside, mixed wit the sound of a DOG BARKING.
All the sounds FADE OUT, save the BARKING. It becomes  rhythmic, constant.
David's eyes flutter open.
Hello, David.
The CORINTHIAN is a young man with silver hair, whipsaw b clothed in white silk pants and T-shirt.
He wears small, round dark glasses and an amused smile.
Hello. How did you get in here?
I wanted to talk to you, David. To tell  you that you are not fulfilling your  potential.
I'm not? Who are you?
I'm your friend. You can call me the  Corinthian. I want to show you something.
He gestures to the TV. The dog continues to BARK.

ON SCREEN: what looks like the opening credits of a mid- seventies cop show: studio backlot heroics and car chases lingers on a POV shot: approaching a parked red Torino. T figures inside, one blond, one brunette -- both women. Th hair is almost ridiculously long and straight.
David leans forward at the sight of the women. His fists  clench. The Corinthian smiles.
I've shown other people things like this,  David. All through history. But none as  special as you.
ON SCREEN: the POV shot continues. A .44 appears in frame and FIRES. The windshield shatters, and the brunette's he snaps back -- a bloodless, TV killing. The blond looks up smiles.
The gun FIRES again.
David's eyes fill with tears of joy. The rhythmic BARKING continues.
You see, David? If you can dream it --  you can be it.
David saddens.
That's all this is? This isn't really  happening? This is a dream?
Sadly, yes. That's the only way  I've  ever talked to special people. But ... (David brightens)
Something has happened, David. And now  you can help me. You can free me. As I  can free you.
How?
The Corinthian smiles, spreads his hands.
Wake up, David. Just wake up.
CLOSE ON: David, sleeping fitfully. His eyes flutter open looks at the TV. The bicentennial footage continues. NORM SOUND has returned.
Just a dream ...
A hand drops on his shoulder. The Corinthian's hand.
Not any more.
He places something on the bed in front of David -- a .44 REVOLVER. David picks it up reverently. Heavy and real.
Good-bye, David. Thank you.
He rises, heads for the door.
Wait! Will I ever see you again? Will you  ... talk with me some more?
The Corinthian pauses.
I'll always be here, David. I'll always  talk to you. Just listen.
Once again, the SOUND fades away, isolating the BARKING D
David listens, nods. The Corinthian nods back, then opens door and leaves. The door shuts quietly -- and NORMAL SOU returns.
David lifts the revolver. Spins the cylinder. POINTS it a the CAMERA --
Burgess leans heavily on a cane. He is now a withered,  fragile old man. He stares at Sandman, who stares back.  Suddenly, Burgess is wracked by a violent coughing attack gets himself under control.
It's your fault! Damn you! (resigned)
You aren't Death, but you live forever.  You haven't aged a day since I caught  you. You could have given me power beyond  my wildest dreams. (chokes back tears)
I ... I didn't have to get so old. I  shouldn't have had to get old.
He has another violent coughing attack. Slips to one knee
That's it, let it out.

Another person is in the cellar. She looks about nineteen Long black hair, pale skin. A kinda groovy, perky neo-pun girl-next-door, dressed in black jeans and camisole. An a the Egyptian symbol for life, hangs from her neck. She lo genuinely concerned for Burgess.
And we recognize her face: it was the face of the angel o death on the grave marker.
Who are you?
She gestures. He looks down. Sees --
His own body. Lying on the ground near his feet. Dead.
Are you ... you aren't Death ... are you?
DEATH smiles, half-shrugs. She knows she's not what he  expected.
Hi.
I tried to catch you once. Got him  instead.
I know.
Am I ... are you going to punish me? Am I  bound for hell?
I'm just here to take you from this world  to the next ... Destinations are up to  you.
Oh ... I am. I'm going to hell. I'm  Roderick Burgess. I'm the most wicked man  alive.
(a bright smile)
Not anymore.
She takes Burgess' hand. Looks up at Sandman.
(genuine sadness)
I'm sorry, little brother ... there's  nothing I can do. I ... I miss you.
She and Burgess fade into the shadows. We hear a SOFT  FLUTTERING SOUND, like WINGS.
She's gone. Just Burgess' body on the floor ... And Sandm watching. The water still DRIPS; the pool in the corner o the room is quite deep now.

Images leading to the present day. A student stands defia in front of a tank. An evangelist breaks down in tears. A white Bronco moves slowly down the freeway. Demonstrators join hands in a field of brightly colored quilts.
In the corner, a DROP of water slips from a pipe, courses down the wall to the floor. Flows along the carved channe the stone, into the pool --
The pool OVERFLOWS. A line of water trickles its way acro the floor, across the faded chalk runes of the circle. It wipes the line of chalk away --
The circle is broken.
With a cry of pain, Sandman falls forward, collapses outs the circle.
He rolls over. Weak. In pain. His lips part. His voice is filled with dark mystery, a voice that can inspire dreams command nightmares:
At ... last.
He gathers himself, rises. Stands, a bit unsteady.
He looks down at the remains of Roderick Burgess, decayed brittle with age. He picks up the skull. Regards it.
Sandman squeezes. The skull SHATTERS. There is no joy in eyes as pieces sift out from between his fingers.
Sandman looks at the shelf that once held his belongings. Empty. He looks away. Moves toward the door --
Sodium lamps cast a sickly yellow light on the nearly-emp lot. A WOMAN hurriedly click-clacks toward her car, keys  already out. She unlocks the door, opens it --
Someone slams it shut: the CORINTHIAN. He has seemingly  appeared from nowhere. He smiles at her.
Beautiful night to be alive, don't you  think?
Stay away from me.
She crouches slightly, flexes her fingers. Her red-painte fingernails glint. She knows self-defense. The Corinthian draws a knife lazily, steps forward.
The Woman kicks at his shin -- he avoids it. But she brin her foot down on his -- hard. She grabs either side of hi head, her thumbs clawing for his eyes behind his sunglass
She SCREAMS, yanks her hands back. She crouches, staring at her hands, which drip with blood.
What did you do?

The Corinthian straightens his sunglasses. The woman craw under the car. The Corinthian grabs her ankle -- she SCRE clutches at the pavement, grabs for the tire, as she is  inexorably dragged out from under the car.
Don't worry. I won't kill you. That would  draw all sorts of the wrong kind of  attention. I just want to look into your  eyes --
Suddenly, she is no longer being dragged. She twists, pee out from under the car --
The Corinthian stands still, looking up toward the night
He's back. He's BACK. No! It's not fair!  I won't allow it. I won't go back!
He looks down at the woman.
Don't worry. I can stop him. I'm not  going back.
She cowers in terror. Opens her eyes -- the Corinthian is gone. She blinks -- it's as if he was never there --
-- except for her hands. The Woman drags herself out from under the car. Raises her hands --
Her THUMBS BLEED, as though bitten through by tiny sharp  teeth. She starts to cry.
Boarded up, windows broken, overgrown. Sandman stands und the night sky. Reaches out his arms. Shadows move, and  darkness stretches towards him.
Sandman wraps the shadows around him --
-- and he is gone.

A SANDSTORM rages; there is the WHITE NOISE of the howlin wind. Shadows flow inside of it, and Sandman's dark outli emerges, one arm raised, a shield against the wind. He pe ahead. In front of him is:

location: THE GATES OF HORN AND IVORY

text: Ornately carved. Flanked by gargoyles. Sandman is relieve the sight.
The Gates of Horn and Ivory. Once  through, I will see my castle ... I will  see --
The gates part before him. Sandman steps through --
-- my home.
Sandman stares in horror --

Ahead of him are the remains of Sandman's Dream Palace.  Beautiful, once, but now overgrown and broken -- its glas walls CRACKED, its delicate spires BROKEN. The majestic  columns have fallen into RUBBLE.
Sandman slumps before it as if struck down. From nearby c the sound of gentle weeping -- and a voice:
Breaks your heart, my Lord, doesn't it?
Sandman turns.
Lucien?
In the shadow of the gates sits LUCIEN, Sandman's librari He rises to his feet. Pointed ears and round spectacles,  dressed as a clown might dress for a formal dinner.
He stares at Sandman, smiling, tears in his eyes. We real he's weeping at Sandman's return.
One and the same, my Lord. (he bows)
At your service, as always. (his voice cracks)
Welcome home.
What happened here?
Lucien takes a breath. Wipes the tears from his eyes.
What happened? You are the incarnation of  this dreamtime, Lord. With you gone, the  place ... it started to crumble ...
He takes off his spectacles, cleans them.

I was aware of it in my Library. Slowly,  the words began to fade. Some time after  you vanished, my books became volumes of  blank paper. The next day the whole  library was gone. (puts on his glasses)
I never found it again.
I'm sorry, Lucien.
I ... I tried, sir. I did my best. We all  did.
Let's see how it is, then.
Sandman moves through the ruined palace, around fallen  columns and past broken statues.
(a sad fact)
Most of the palace servants turned back  into the dream stuff you made them with --
He's back? He's really back?
A WILD FLAPPING SOUND and a sleek black raven -- MATTHEW  streaks down, hovers in front of Sandman.
Where have you BEEN? Are you all right?  What happened?
I was detained.
Ha. Detained. You haven't changed, that's  good news.
Nor have you, Matthew.
Sandman surveys the devastation.
It's a pisser, ain't it?
It hurts me, too, lord.
Hurts, yes ... Some power returns to me,  simply by being here. But I placed too  much of myself in my tools. And they are  gone.
He sits down on a broken marble stair.
I wonder ... I wonder if it is all even  worth rebuilding.
Matthew speaks an aside to Lucien, not all that quietly:
Hell, I wonder if he can.
Lucien shoots Matthew a scolding look.
My Lord -- some things you should know,  items that need attention right away.  Many of the nightkind are missing. Lesser  dreams. And ...  (he swallows)
One of the major nightmares.
Sandman cocks an eyebrow, waiting. Lucien doesn't like be the messenger.
The Corinthian. Escaped into the waking  world, I'm afraid.

Sandman turns away. Before him is his reflection in a cra mirror, hanging askew on a wall. He looks up into his own eyes a moment, then away -- and in the mirror, we get a  glimpse of a fat, gray face -- DESPAIR.
How long?
Twenty years.
There is no telling the harm he may have  caused in that time. (beat)
I blame myself. Had I been here,  fulfilling my function ...
Aww ... it wasn't your fault, boss.
No? Then whose? (beat)
And, in my absence, how much further  havoc has been visited upon the waking  world?

FACES of SLEEPING PEOPLE, as seen on a row of black-and-w video monitors. Cheap public-sector equipment -- out of d out of focus, one of the screens flipping endlessly. Belo each monitor EKGs slowly churn out reams of graph paper.
A DOCTOR moves down the line, checking the readouts with  professional indifference.

ON SCREEN: A man sleeps peacefully -- his name is PAUL - then his legs twitch spasmodically, stop. A piece of mask tape is hand-labeled 'PLMS/nocturnal myoclonus.' NEXT SCR An ELDERLY MAN begins thrashing in bed, SCREAMING, pullin out electrodes. His eyes are open but he sees nothing.
(checks his watch)
Patient seventeen, night terror episode  at eleven-oh-five.
The Doctor expects a response, doesn't get it. He turns,  glances down the line -- where an ASSISTANT studies the  length of an EKG read-out, engrossed.
Did you get that?
(re: the read-out)
It's gotta be some kind of record. Three  day observation program, and she's never  made it past a level 2 sleep pattern.  Even then just for a few minutes.
The Doctor looks interested for the first time, comes ove leaving patient seventeen behind, still SCREAMING.
Three days without REM sleep? She should  see things crawling the walls by now.
No sign of hallucinations.  She's part of the benzodiazepine study  ...
What's her name?
ON SCREEN: is a WOMAN, lovely, her face relaxed in the  peaceful beauty of sleep -- but here eyes are wide open,  staring enigmatically INTO CAMERA, unblinking.
Rose Walker.
ROSE WALKER, dressed, quickly packs a few items into an  overnight bag. The Doctor appears in the doorway. He turn envelope in his hands.
We do appreciate your participation, Miss  Walker. Um, if we could persuade you,  we'd like to have you back for an  individual --
(cuts him off)

Yeah, yeah, I know. Lemme guess. I'm  special. You've never seen anything like  me. You want to run blood tests and do a  night-time polysomnogram.  Maybe you'll  do a daytime multiple sleep latency test.  You'll find that my condition is non- respiratory, and not stress induced.  You'll find my eye muscles lack tone  because my REM sleep is so rare, but you  won't know why. (beat)
Is that the check?
Yes --
Rose plucks it from his hands. She slings her overnight b over her shoulder.

Look, no offense, but ... I've been  monitored and studied and hooked up to  wires since I was ten. If I thought there  was any chance that you guys could get me  a good night's sleep, I'd take you up on  it. But --
She shrugs. A wave of the envelope, and she's gone.
The envelope is torn open; Rose examines the check.
How'd you do?
PAUL -- who we met briefly, a patient in the sleep center has been waiting. He wears a clean denim shirt, and one o those wispy goatees favored by sensitive-artist types.
It'll get me through another semester.  You?
Same. Walk you home?
... sure.
Paul notes the reluctance in her voice.
Listen, Rose ... I'm sorry I ... Sorry  that ...
Rose glances at him from under raised eyebrows, a smile  playing across her lips.
Yes, Paul..?
That I couldn't talk to you ... after the  other night.
Paul ... don't worry about it. We just  had some kind of emotional meltdown and  we ended up in bed. It's been known to  happen.
Commuters exit the BART station. Rose and Paul pause, pul skateboards from their bags. They ride expertly downhill, winding in and out of the pedestrians.
Skateboards in hand, Rose and Paul trudge up a steep hill
I really wasn't looking for, uh, you  know. I was just ... I've been blocked  for so long, and you listen so easy. (beat)
I was afraid that I'd, I don't know,  seduced you --
